content: As Azmax said, "I gotta play nice" I so enjoyed being one of the bad boys. I don't wanna do 3 day's on bread and water in the brig. The consensus here is stay put, wait until Nathan is finished with basic. That is good advice. Basic goes by fast for the recruit, you just have to bide your time. Hang in there, It'll work out! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: As Azmax said, "I gotta play nice" I so enjoyed being one of the bad boys. I don't wanna do 3 day's on bread and water in the brig. The consensus here is stay put, wait until Nathan is finished with basic. That is good advice. Basic goes by fast for the recruit, you just have to bide your time. Hang in there, It'll work out! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
title: I am an Airman's Girlfirend

content: Guess I gotta put my 'mister nice guy face on' this time... Not a good idea to follow your fella to his base and try to have the both of you take up all that 'out of school' time... Flat slap plain and simple fact of the matter is that HE WILL NOT HAVE THAT MUCH SPARE TIME ON HIS HANDS AFTER SCHOOL HOURS! What little spare time on his hands will be taken up studying, keeping his uniforms up to snuff, as well as doing his share keeping quarters up to par. Plus, he may well have to pull duty from time to time... And, if he is of lower rank (E-1, E-2 or E-3) his chances of getting off post will be slim to none. In some cases, having a personal vehicle during schooling is a no-no...depending on the rules set up by said school. Just stay home and write letters...
reply: Guess I gotta put my 'mister nice guy face on' this time... Not a good idea to follow your fella to his base and try to have the both of you take up all that 'out of school' time... Flat slap plain and simple fact of the matter is that HE WILL NOT HAVE THAT MUCH SPARE TIME ON HIS HANDS AFTER SCHOOL HOURS! What little spare time on his hands will be taken up studying, keeping his uniforms up to snuff, as well as doing his share keeping quarters up to par. Plus, he may well have to pull duty from time to time... And, if he is of lower rank (E-1, E-2 or E-3) his chances of getting off post will be slim to none. In some cases, having a personal vehicle during schooling is a no-no...depending on the rules set up by said school. Just stay home and write letters...
title: I am an Airman's Girlfirend
